searchDocs.title: Roblox Studio​
searchDocs.content: Get NeoHotbar from the toolbox.Place the loader into StarterPlayer/StarterPlayerScriptsIf you want to use the API, you can take the module out of the loader script.

searchDocs.title: Rojo + Wally​
searchDocs.content: Add NeoHotbar as a Wally dependency.Run :Start() on NeoHotbar from a client-side script.    That's all you need to do to use NeoHotbar! Now you can leave it as-is or get into customization. ✨

searchDocs.title: Start​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:Start() → () Initializes NeoHotbar and deploys its UI with default settings.

searchDocs.title: SetEnabled​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:SetEnabled( Enabled: boolean-- Whether or not to enable NeoHotbar. ) → () Sets whether NeoHotbar or not is enabled. Disabling hides the hotbar and turns off keybinds.

searchDocs.title: SetToolTipsEnabled​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:SetToolTipsEnabled( Enabled: boolean-- Whether or not to enable. ) → () Sets whether or not ToolTips are enabled.

searchDocs.title: SetManagementEnabled​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:SetManagementEnabled( Enabled: boolean-- Whether or not to enable. ) → () Sets whether or not players can rearrange the tools in their hotbar.

searchDocs.title: SetContextMenuEnabled​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:SetContextMenuEnabled( Enabled: boolean-- Whether or not to enable. ) → () Sets whether or not players can open the context menu. (the one that appears when you right click on a tool)

searchDocs.title: OverrideGui​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:OverrideGui( CustomGuiSet: Folder ,-- The parent folder containing your custom Gui objects. DefaultEffectsEnabled: boolean?-- Whether or not to enable NeoHotbar's built-in UI effects. Not compatible with ultra-customized themes. ) → () Overrides NeoHotbar's UI with a new set of Gui objects.

searchDocs.title: ResetGui​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:ResetGui() → () Reset NeoHotbar's UI back to the default.

searchDocs.title: AddCustomButton​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:AddCustomButton( ButtonName: string,-- The name/identifier of the button to be added. IconImage: string,-- The image URI to be used on the button icon. E.g. "rbxassetid://". Callback: any,-- The function called upon button activation (click/touch/etc). GamepadKeybind: EnumItem? -- A gamepad keycode to trigger your custom button. ) → () Adds a custom button to the hotbar, prepended to the left-most side.

searchDocs.title: RemoveCustomButton​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:RemoveCustomButton( ButtonName: string-- The name of the button to be removed. ) → () Removes the specified custom button from the hotbar.

searchDocs.title: FindCustomButton​
searchDocs.content: </> NeoHotbar:FindCustomButton( ButtonName: string-- The name of the button to be searched for. ) → () Returns the specified custom button if found.

searchDocs.title: Custom buttons​
searchDocs.content: You can add your own custom buttons to NeoHotbar, like to open a backpack for example!  First, find an image to use for the button's icon. Next, let's add the button to NeoHotbar. We'll use the image's asset ID and a callback function to tell NeoHotbar what to do when it's clicked. local NeoHotbar = require(path.to.NeoHotbar) NeoHotbar:AddCustomButton("rbxassetid://0", function() print('Button was clicked!') end) You're done! You can hook this button up to whatever you want in your game.

searchDocs.title: Custom UI​
searchDocs.content: NeoHotbar's UI is fully overridable, so you can customize it however you like!  Copy over the default UI to use as a template. The folder can be found in NeoHotbar/DefaultInstances.Modify all you like, you have full control!Call :OverrideGui() on NeoHotbar, passing your folder as an argument.

searchDocs.title: Dynamic attributes​
searchDocs.content: You can also plug into dynamic attributes to have your UI react to changes.  For example, the ToolButton component has an attribute called Equipped. Here's what a code snippet for that might look like:  local ToolButton = path.to.ToolButton local function ReactToEquipped(Equipped: boolean) print(`Equipped: {Equipped}`) end ToolButton:GetAttributeChangedSignal("Equipped"):Connect(function() ReactToEquipped(ToolButton:GetAttribute("Equipped")) end) ReactToEquipped(ToolButton:GetAttribute("Equipped"))   You may also choose to use a UI library like Fusion to handle reactive logic. Fun fact, NeoHotbar uses Fusion behind the scenes itself.

searchDocs.title: Properties​
searchDocs.content: You might want to change simpler things, like temporarily hiding the hotbar or locking tool reordering. You can set those properties with the functions listed here:  SetEnabledSetManagementEnabledSetToolTipsEnabledSetContextMenuEnabled
